THE CASE FOR RENOIR- Which Impressionists thought women, children and family life were worthy subjects for art? Cassatt, Morisot and Renoir. In fact (and please correct me if I'm wrong) I am hard-pressed to think of any male artists, in any age, who celebrated domestic life, or who seemed to actually like women and children like Renoir did. I'm a wife and mother - There are many other facets to me, but my family and domestic life are very important to me and take up a large proportion of my time, yet I rarely see them explored in art. Some of the Victorians did so, but in a very maudlin, overly sentimental way. Other children in art are royalty. Some of the other Impressionists painted real women, but they were either part of the landscape (Monet), modern goddesses (Manet) or exercises in the most magnificent draftsmanship (Degas). Only the three artists above feel relatable to my family and, of those, only Renoir is a man - and for that reason I make a case for Renoir.
